/*
 * extension.txt
 * Author: Haiyu Huang, Kyle Chang
 * Date:   November 23, 2016
 *  
 * README for extension project
 */

Abstract:
For our extension project, we analyzed twitter retweet data during the 
higgs boson discovery to find strongly connected componenets between users.
We were looking to see if we could find tight knit communities in twitter where
users would tend to mutually retweet each other. The data was a list 
of pairs of id's where the first user retweeted the second user. First we
read in the data into a vector of pairs of integers. The graph itself was an
unordered map, where the key was the id number and object linked was a Node *.
Inside each node is a vector which stores all edgeset or all the neighbors the
the node is attached to. We inserted all the items from the read in data into
this map. After, we started creating our first graph and connecting the edges,
which was essentially filling in the edgesets in each node. Then we began the
DFS traversals by pushing the  vertices onto a stack, and calling DFS traversal
 on those vertices to create another stack of finished verticies. Then we 
cleared the edgeset of the graph and then created a transpose of the graph. The
transpose of the graph was really just the original graph except the edges were
reversed. This was used to run a second DFS traversal on to find the SCC of 
the graph. We used a multi set so for each id, we could have a vector of all the
strongly connected components of that  To test our extension file, we created
 a test file with the data set used in link four from the 
writeup. To replicate these results, the grader should run our program 
with "./extension twitter_higgs.txt output" and then cat the output to find
all SCC from twitter_higgs.txt. Below we have the two test cases we used and how
to replicate our tests; the data set from the coursera and the twitter higgs 
data. 




Test case 1 :
Input file : test  ( the sample directed graph from the video )
How to compile:    make or make extension
How to run:        ./extension test output

Output:
25 23 18 65 
44 
50 
32 

Analysis:
	As we can see from the output of a simple sample graph, we show that 
	our algorithm to generate strongly connected component is correct on a 
	small scale as we compare our result to what Professor Alvarado showed
	in the video.




Test case 2 :
Input file : twitter_higgs.txt
How to compile:    make or make extension
How to run:        ./extension twitter_higgs.txt output

Output:

4904 287362 61332 178415 40261 58980 57530 33274 33302 33301 26186 34963 20919 14682 33642 11692 12751 26158 13808 45605 73710 43722 138766 84219 88355 12928 531 30790 103759 37443 44183 13235 20718 ......

Analysis:
	Above the first twentieth strongly connected component of the community formed from retweeting 
	during the time of the discovery of higgs boson. As shown in the data, there is a huge 
	community of retweeting one another in the first line of output. The
following lines tend to get shorter and shorter, which makes sense as there
would most likely be a lot more retweeting at the start of the discovery and
less as news of the discovery became more known. From this extension project, we
were able to use our new-found knowledge in graphs to break down a large amount
of data (just columns of id numbers!) into information that can be used for
further research or spark discussion.
